Although conflict is the complete breakdown of law and order, the ultimate objective of any professional army is to return to law and order, to return the established systems where there is safety and security for all. The use of antipersonnel mines in an undetectable and indiscriminate fashion during conflict has a horrific aftermath and a cost to civilians, who, quite clearly, since 1945, have not been the target of any attack or military objective.

Mines are incredibly cheap to make. They can be built in garages, fields or kitchens. They generally tend to be the preferred weapon of choice in underdeveloped countries. The time is well past for Australia to take a stand in leading the attitude to a professional deployment of military power. The statements by the minister to date have gone a fair way to doing that and Australia's ratification of these protocols heads that way, as well.

The other protocol mentioned concerns laser weapons. As yet, we are still feeling our way in this murky field of law to come to some understanding and standards which will be considered humane. Man's arms race is certainly ahead of itself on this one. We currently use lasers to designate targets for guided bomb systems. What is the effect of those? What is the effect from that of now moving forward to developing the laser itself as the projectile rather than a bullet, with the terrible consequences of blindness or the aftermath on the civilian population in a conflict? This was clearly seen with the use of mustard gas in World War I.

Loss of eyesight and the subsequent consequences to society in dealing with the costs of blindness and retraining and reskilling people who have lost such a substantial part of their independence have already been seen throughout history. We must move slowly towards finding acceptable standards and uses for this technology that comes up every day from our scientists and engineers, who are constantly pushing back the frontiers of science.

It is something that I feel very strongly about. I think Australia should be leading world opinion. Without the modern armies doing so, we have little hope of underdeveloped countries taking the same professional attitude to the deployment of military power. That has an adverse consequence on our military personnel when they come up against an opponent who does not comply with the laws of war.

That was clearly seen in the recent Gulf War in the Middle East. The Iraqi military forces had used chemical weapons against the Iranians in their previous eight‐year war, but they failed to do so in the Gulf War. They respected the discipline of the forces that were there, in an acknowledgment that they would not use chemical weapons. A balance was achieved in terms of warfare that was conducted quite clearly within the bounds of the laws of war, the Geneva conventions, the subsequent protocols and all the other treaties that we continually develop in the international sphere in the hope of attaining some form of international agreement on what is the definition of a crime against humanity. I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hardgrave, Gary, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to participate in the discussion of the report that I was very proud to have played a part in compiling. The fifth report of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties is certainly worthy of debate here today and its discussion is a very important national as well as international matter. Restrictions on the use of blinding laser weapons and land mines: 5th report is the name of the report. The joint standing treaties committee will next week table its ninth report in less than a year.

SPEECH.PARA: I have to say it was privilege enough for me to have been elected to this place to represent the good people of the electorate of Moreton. It was an unexpected honour to be appointed by the parliament to the joint standing treaties committee and to participate in a very important process, the deliberation and consideration of the international linkages that Australia has. Certainly, a criticism often offered to me in the lead‐up to the last election was that there were just so many agreements that Australia had with other countries and other entities around the world and that there really was no accounting back to the parliament.

It is a great credit to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) to have embraced an agenda first put forward by Senator Rod Kemp of Victoria—now Assistant Treasurer—to have this treaties process. It is very important that the consideration of treaties and international agreements of all types is not just the domain of the executive or the foreign affairs club. We have been able to break through the obvious and natural barriers of the bureaucracy in the committee process to expose a number of very important issues to date.

The committee's work range has included everything from tuna fishing through to the rights of the child, which is the current inquiry. This report before us is one that I was very pleased to be part of for a number of reasons. I will mention a couple of them. It helped me to keep faith, as a member in this place, with a lot of people who wrote to me prior to the election looking for some action on just this issue. People from Catholic Social Response, the International Red Cross, Amnesty International and others all have an interest, naturally enough, in the use of landmines. They are simply one of the most cowardly forms of weaponry used by armies around the world.

I am very pleased to be part of a government whose Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer), on 15 April last year—in essentially one of the first acts of the new government—deplored the use of landmines and stated very clearly Australia's position. As the honourable member for Lindsay (Miss Jackie Kelly) just said, we have a vital leadership role in our region, particularly to show countries such as Cambodia—with not just its killing fields but also its maiming fields—that we do not believe the use of landmines is good enough. I join with the honourable member for Lindsay, and I am sure others in this place, in calling on the government to get even tougher on the use of landmines.

They are simply horrendous weapons. They leave in their wake children, particularly, who, after conflicts, may wander into fields, into what would normally be productive areas, and trip over these things. They are not designed to kill; they are designed to maim. They were designed to maim sections of the opposing army because it paralyses an army. It is bad enough when a soldier is killed, but when a soldier is injured two other soldiers are then taken out to carry that injured soldier. There is at least a triplication effect with these sorts of weapons. So we now have in countries in our region children innocently tripping over landmines and losing limbs. The photos in this report provided by Dr William Maley are just too horrendous to contemplate, with large rafts of skin being torn off innocent children. Landmines have to go.

BREAK.PARA: Landmines are quite easy to make. They are literally being made in people's kitchens and underneath people's homes. In fact, it is quite astonishing to note, and we received evidence to suggest this, that some of the very best electrical companies around the world have their components stuck inside some of these landmines. I am not about to advocate that we should be putting a ban on products that are also produced by these companies—because I suspect, in their defence, a lot of the materials used are simply cast off components that have been picked up by those who want to make these bombs and who do so, literally, on the kitchen table.

They are everywhere. As the honourable member for Lindsay has alluded to, and this is contained within the report, antipersonnel landmines total 400 million since the Second World War. The US State Department has estimated that there are more than 85 million uncleared landmines scattered in 62 countries around the world, and five million new landmines are being laid each and every year, with a cost of up to $US1,000 to clear each mine.

There is evidence from the International Red Cross that for every landmine cleared 20 additional are laid. It would cost in the vicinity of $US33 billion to rid the world of this scourge. We are not about to get rid of landmines tomorrow. I certainly wished that I could have been part of a process that had got rid of landmines but I think the important part about this report is that it states very clearly the view of the parliament. I am glad to see the government is going down the same track. Landmines are dreadful devices and they should be taken out of the play, as far as the world is concerned.

I think it is also important to note the evidence of Dr William Maley with regard to some of the ways that these landmines are quite deliberately being used. The last thing a retreating army does is to lay landmines in and around hospitals, schools and fields that can be used for food production. It is a quite deliberate and cowardly device used by a retreating army to inflict horrendous psychological and physical damage on the opposing side when they reclaim the land.

As I said, I was proud to be part of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties in the compilation of this report. I am very pleased that we have discussed this here today and I urge the government to continue its efforts to rid the world of these mines. Also, in closing, I wish to register my praise for the role of the Australian defence forces, who quite rightly maintain a small stock of landmines here in this country in order to train and to maintain their expertise in order to continue their important role in ridding the world of these devices. Australian Defence Force personnel are amongst the best in clearing landmines, and God speed to their work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Truss, Warren, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I join the previous speakers in expressing satisfaction that this report of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties is being given time for debate in the Main Committee today. This was, of course, a very important inquiry by the treaties committee. The committee was required to respond to a proposal by the government to sign these particular protocols, but it was also a very heart‐wrenching experience for the members of the committee. As the previous speaker mentioned, the committee was exposed to really horrific photographic evidence of the effects of landmines, and a couple of those photographs were reproduced in the committee's report.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition to that we had to deal with fairly complex issues. Whilst everyone has a horror of war and a horror of the tools of war, there is a recognition of the fact that our country cannot leave itself defenceless in the event of our nation being subjected to some kind of threat. So it is important to strike a balance between a desire to act humanely, even in times of war and national distress, and being able to adequately defend our country.

It is, perhaps, a reflection of the fact that these issues were difficult that there was a minority report. I think that this is the only report of the treaties committee that included a minority report and I want to talk a little bit about the issues in that minority report in my contribution today.

We have the benefit during this debate of having also at our disposal the government's response to the report. So we have the evidence of not only the six recommendations, but also the way in which the government has responded to these proposals. Whilst the government has not accepted all of the recommendations, I think the response has generally been reasonable.

The first matter dealt with by the committee was protocol IV dealing with blinding laser weapons. It needs to be emphasised right at the beginning that blinding laser weapons are still in the developmental phase and there is no evidence that they have ever been used in conflict to date. In prohibiting a yet to be invented—yet to be fully developed—weapon, protocol IV is dealing with largely experimental or unexplored territory. But it is recognised that this is a major advance. It is obviously far better to ban a horrible weapon before it is used than to merely respond to international outrage after it has been used in conflict. So in that regard this protocol breaks new ground, and it is very pleasing to note that Australia will be amongst the first countries to assent to this protocol.

One of the witnesses to the committee made the point that the protocol actually bans only the use and transfer of blinding laser weapons and not their actual production or development. So we could still see some degree of experimental work being done, although to no avail for those countries who have actually signed the protocol.

The risk with this protocol—indeed, with all rules of war—is that the despotic regimes who are perhaps less concerned about humanitarian issues, those who might be most likely to use these kinds of weapons if they could gain access to them, are the ones that will not sign the protocol. So countries that have a more responsible attitude are naturally concerned about the exposure of their troops or their people in wartime to a weapon that they have voluntarily chosen not to use. So, in a sense, many countries are adopting something of a defensive mechanism by saying that they are prepared to work on the technology but will not actually use it when the time comes.

There is also no absolute ban under protocol IV on the use of lasers in wartime, merely on the use of blinding laser weapons. There has already been use of lasers in guidance systems, and I think there is likely to be a lot more development in that regard. I am not sure that is necessarily inhumane. Lasers provide considerable enhancement to the accuracy of weapons, and that is likely to make them better able to target a military objective rather than indiscriminately slaughtering humans. I think there is likely to be substantial further development of laser guidance systems, and that will probably be an advancement rather than a disadvantage. Australia has indicated that it will be moving to sign this protocol and to commit our country to its obligations.
The other area that has been covered has been the question of antipersonnel landmines. This has been a matter of considerable distress, widespread—

PARA.EMPHASIS: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—
Sitting suspended from 11.46 a.m. to 11.58 a.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension, I was about to commence some comments on the issue of landmines and the committee's report on amended protocol II, which deals with mines, booby traps and other devices. It again needs to be pointed out that this protocol does not actually talk about banning these weapons but merely talks about prohibiting or restricting the use of particular mines. The Australian government has responded in a positive way in relation to this protocol. Antipersonnel landmines contained in the Australian defence stockpile basically comply with the restrictions required under the revised protocol II, although I understand that the M14 mines would need minor modification if they were ever to be used in the future.

BREAK.PARA: On 15 April 1996, the Minister for Defence (Mr McLachlan) and the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) announced a unilateral suspension by Australia of the operational use of antipersonnel landmines by the Australian Defence Force and that the measure would take effect immediately. It is important to note that Australia does not actually produce or export landmines itself.

The government indicated that the suspension would, for all intents and purposes, be permanent. It would be subject to review only in the case of a substantial deterioration in our strategic situation. The Australian government is retaining a national antipersonnel landmine stockpile to provide a defensive capability in the event of substantial deterioration in Australia's strategic circumstances,

The committee, as I mentioned earlier, was divided on the issue of the extent of Australia's response on antipersonnel landmines. The majority of the committee recommended that Australia destroy its stockpile of antipersonnel landmines, except for a small number to be retained for training purposes to ensure that the Australian Defence Force retains its skill. In other words, the committee was recommending unilateral action by Australia to destroy its stockpile, an action which I understand Canada has already taken. It would certainly provide a very strong lead to the world that Australia regarded the use of these sorts of weapons as unacceptable.

There was, however, a significant minority report which recommended that Australia should declare its willingness to destroy its landmines, except for training stock. It should only destroy the rest of its landmines once a substantial number of significant nations in our region have committed themselves to this course according to an agreed international timetable. The question arose as to whether Australia should undertake the symbolic act of destroying its landmines to demonstrate to the world that these weapons were regarded as unacceptable, or whether our assurance not to use them and not to review that assurance unless we were subject to significant threat is a more reasonable response.

I have to say that, on balance, I come down on the side of the government's position. I do so because Australia is a vast country. It is a nation that is not threatened at the present time. Frankly, I doubt that our country will be threatened in the future. I certainly hope that that is the case. We need to do all that we can as a nation diplomatically to ensure that we retain a cordial relationship with our neighbours. But there is a possibility that our situation could deteriorate. Any prudent country will always plan also for the circumstances when it must defend itself. To unilaterally disarm when no‐one else in our neighbourhood would be taking such action would be regarded by many as foolhardy.

We also need to recognise that our nation has a very large coastline that is almost impossible to defend with traditional armaments, no matter how powerful our defence forces might be. Of course, we have the benefit of wonderful new technology, early radar defence systems and the like. But it is conceivable that, if an invasion was threatened, with the availability of the sorts of weapons that we know exist at this time, Australia may need to use antipersonnel landmines to defend itself from a military invasion. Such weapons should only be used in those sorts of circumstances.

There are a wide range of other rules in protocol II, and in the various rules of war, about the way in which landmines should be used. Sadly, it has been an ignorance of those laws which has been a part of the destruction and damage and injury to people in Asia and other parts of the world. The existing protocols have not worked in many of those countries. Sadly, for the same reasons as I referred to at the beginning of my remarks, there is a risk that the new protocol rules may not work in those countries as well.

The government has made it clear that it regards the use of these weapons as unacceptable, and that Australia itself will not use landmines. The government has also indicated its willingness to look at the second part of the committee's recommendation, which was that Australia should prepare for consideration at the December 1997 meeting in Canada a proposal for the creation of an agreed international timetable for the destruction of antipersonnel landmines of all nations.

This takes up the point of the minority report. Australia stands ready to destroy its own landmines, but would like to act in concert with other nations so that our whole region would be rid of these appallingly destructive weapons. As was mentioned earlier by the member for Lindsay (Miss Jackie Kelly) in particular, this is a weapon that is designed as much to harm innocent civilians as it is to stem the flow or advance of an army. Such a deployment of landmines is a clear abuse of a whole range of Geneva conventions, but those conventions have not prevented it from happening. They have not prevented the appalling injuries that were referred to earlier.

What we do need is a strong diplomatic offensive to seek an agreement by all of the countries of our region—indeed, hopefully all of the countries in the world—to move to eliminate antipersonnel landmines. Australia has indicated that it is prepared to act cooperatively with other countries in that regard. I commend to the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Foreign Affairs the proposal that they should pursue this objective strongly when the meeting occurs in Canada later this year.

Mr Deputy Speaker, these two protocols have the potential to help make the world a safer place, to free the world of the threat of some of the most potentially and actually horrific weapons that are used from time to time in war. Australia has an honourable record in defence of our country and in wartime. We have been involved in conflicts, however, where the conventions have frequently been ignored. I hope that there will be international effort to ensure that our world is made safer by the elimination of these sorts of weapons.
Debate (on motion by Mr Griffin) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 27 August, on motion by Mr Reith:
That the House take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The government response to the Joint Statutory Committee on the National Crime Authority's report on organised criminal paedophile activity, which has followed the publication of the report in November 1995, is a timely one. It comes at the same time that the Wood royal commission has released the final report into its inquiries into paedophile activity and other aspects relating to the corruption in the New South Wales police force.

SPEECH.PARA: I was a sponsor of this particular inquiry, and visited the National Criminal Intelligence Service in the United Kingdom last year. I might point out to those who may not be aware that this is now considered to be one of the authorities for material related to research into organised or other paedophile activity.

I might also point out that the recommendations of that particular report coincide neatly with the findings of the Wood royal commission with relation to the extent of organised criminal paedophile activity, and also some other aspects. I must say this, though: one of the things I would strongly object to in relation to the Wood royal commission's findings is the proposal to reduce the age of consent for homosexual behaviour to 16 years. I would strongly oppose that for a variety of reasons, which I might touch on later if I have time.

The most important thing is to look at the circumstances surrounding the release of both the report and the response by the federal government. The report came at a time when there was considerable debate and speculation in the community about the extent to which organised criminal paedophile activity was operating in the community. At the same time we were perhaps 10 months down the track from the introduction of legislation that made it an offence to participate in child sex tourism—some groundbreaking legislation.

In fairness to the previous Labor government, it was initiated by the Labor government, under Minister Kerr at the time, and has proved not to be a blinding success, but at least it has been available as part of the array of weapons against the sort of behaviour that most people would find totally reprehensible. Australians unfortunately were beginning to get the reputation for being some of the worst offenders in the cases where, because of our proximity to some of these areas of attraction, tours were being organised and people were visiting these particular areas solely for the purpose of accessing juveniles for sexual purposes.

When we made these recommendations, there were some concerns about the extent to which the Australian law enforcement authorities were getting cooperation from their counterparts overseas, in particular in Thailand. One of the recommendations was to look at beefing up the relationship, the liaison, between the Thai police and the Australian Federal Police. At the time, the Thai police had something in the region of 150,000 police officers but only four were allocated as liaison officers to the Australian Federal Police. Considering the amount of drug trafficking investigation and detection which was taking place, this tended to give the impression that they viewed the child sex tourism area with a very low priority indeed. In fact, there were a number of allegations—to us and elsewhere during the debate that gave rise to the child sex tourism legislation in the first place—that corrupt officials, corruption within the criminal system within Thailand, impeded the investigative work of people trying to get to the bottom of, or trying to investigate, particular cases.

We are now halfway through the term of the Howard government, a government elected to strengthen the role of the family in the community. Paedophile activity is very closely related to this. For instance, the statistics from the Wood royal commission show that 46 per cent of proven victims are assaulted by family members. Fifty‐four per cent of proven victims are assaulted by a non‐family member; of those, 44 per cent are assaulted by an adult known to the family. In this case, one can clearly see that there is a very strong need, a very serious need, to strengthen, not weaken, the opportunity for the family unit to be able to be an influence against paedophile behaviour. It is also a fact, not refuted, that many assaults are undertaken in the case of de facto relationships by a de facto stepfather on a stepdaughter. This is another area of concern.

But what concerns me most is the fact that, notwithstanding the commitment of the Howard government to beefing up the family unit as the principal source of comfort, care, love and education in our community, there are aspects of government policy that are undermining and weakening substantially the opportunity for families to be able to combat the influence of paedophile behaviour.

I can give you a few examples from my own electorate, ones that have occurred very recently. Amongst some more recent ones was a case where two 14‐year‐old girls ran away from home. They met up with some youths in town, who then persuaded them to come and live at their place, which was like an open house, effectively under the control of a woman who was seeing a number of men. These girls moved there unbeknownst to their parents. They were believed to be participating in drug taking, in sexual activity on the premises. One of them ended up getting assaulted, their health suffered and their condition and welfare were seriously under question.

The interesting thing was that, notwithstanding the fact that their father reported the girls missing immediately, the police could not tell the father where these girls were. The police would not act to bring these girls back home. Under the circumstances, I would have considered that to be entirely reprehensible. At the same time, the state department—that is, the family and community services department of the Western Australia government, another coalition government, I might add, in its second term of government—also failed to act, under the act which it has responsibility for administering.

So we have the situation where the father appeared on the Howard Sattler program—one of Perth's popular radio talk back shows—and quizzed the Premier one month after the girls had actually disappeared. The Premier said that he would get the minister to act immediately on this. Within the period that the Premier was informed and the matter came back to my attention, one of the girls had been assaulted so badly that she had to have stitches around her eye. We understand that there were other men coming into the household and sexual activity had taken place with these girls, who were 14‐year‐old twins. In fact, when one went to a doctor's surgery, she collapsed from malnutrition in the doctor's surgery.

Interestingly enough, when the woman that was acting in loco parentis, so to speak, for these girls went to the Department of Social Security in her local area—a federal department—she was able to get family allowance payments for the girls. Then the Department of Social Security wrote to the parents and told them they had to repay the money they had received as family allowance payments. Eventually, after contacting the minister, we got an apology from the minister's office for what is, in my view, entirely reprehensible behaviour by the Department of Social Security.

It gives an indication of just how serious the problem is. If a parent is conscious of their child being under threat or if the child leaves home before they are of the age of sexual consent, then they have little to no influence over that child's welfare—to such an extent that a government department would be very reluctant to return that child to the home, even if they were of the opinion that that particular child was engaging in under‐age sexual activity.

Where we have the government yesterday saying that it wanted to do something about this terrible problem of paedophile activity—and it is a terrible problem—we have the situation where, within its own departments, it is in fact encouraging the very behaviour through its own lack of support for the role of the parents.

The other problem is: what does the government do under the circumstances? The government has responded to a range of recommendations made by our committee and in most cases they have agreed to them. In particular, of course, the most important of those, as far as the Commonwealth government is concerned, is in the circulation of information relating to the activities of paedophiles. It is quite clear that paedophiles, by their nature, gravitate to their place of opportunity—to the place where they can access their prey. In many instances, they move from place to place. You would be perhaps totally unfamiliar with the fact that across the road from your children lived somebody who may have been convicted for sexually assaulting children—who may have served a prison sentence and come back to live in the community.

We have seen in the United States a considerable social movement, a popular movement, to have legislation enacted by President Clinton to in fact make it mandatory for local authorities to inform the local community in the case where somebody with that sort of criminal background moves into the community. We have seen instances where people of that particular nature have moved back in and recommitted offences. People who were living across the road, or in that community, did not know because the authorities would not tell them.

We have this similar problem here in Australia, where, for instance, a parent, in anguish, goes to a government department, state or federal, asking for help to get their daughter or son away from a situation in which they are in sexual activity with people who are over the age of consent or adults—in other words paedophile activity. They cannot get any help, notwithstanding the fact that there is legislation there to actually guide them or to provide that power.

There is a policy in the family and children's services department in Western Australia not to enforce it—not to return the child to their home. In fact, the policy is to take the view of the child if the child wilfully wants to engage in this activity. One of the reasons why I strongly oppose the reduction of the age of consent for homosexual behaviour is that it is a well-known fact that adult homosexual males prey on juvenile males in a way that contributes to the behaviour. In fact, many of them are more prosperous or they spend lots of money and do things to try and smother the person or to make the person feel comfortable or happy in their company and then use that to break down any perhaps resistance or natural concerns they might have about behaviour. It is quite clear, particularly when you look at some of the evidence that has arisen as a result of the New South Wales royal commission, that in fact this is still going on today to a wide extent.

BREAK.PARA: I personally would like to congratulate two people who have done a good job in relation to their parliamentary duties in New South Wales. They are on the other side of the fence politically from me, but they are people who have taken a stand on it and have actually done something. I think that members of parliament have a duty to act where they feel that it is in the interests of the community to act. I refer to Franca Arena and Deirdre Grusovin, who were reviled in the media at one stage and then praised at another. They took it upon themselves to use their parliamentary privilege, something that is a privilege to all of us, to act on behalf of their constituents. That is what it is for.

In both cases, in my view, they have been shown to have made a contribution. It is quite clear that, in the absence of action and in the absence of people taking it upon themselves to act, the problem has gotten out of hand in New South Wales and has given rise to this royal commission there.

I would like also to make an observation in relation to the problem that we touched upon in our particular report relating to Cambodia. World Vision gave evidence to us in Melbourne that there was the very serious problem of paedophiles accessing World Vision child sponsorship programs, becoming a sponsor and then going to the country where the child lived and accessing that child for sexual purposes, knowing full well that in many instances, both culturally and because of their particular circumstance of poverty, the parents may well not resist the overtures made by that particular paedophile activist.

I have also been very disappointed over the period of time since the allegations were first raised about the role of Australia's mission in Cambodia in relation to paedophile activity because it is now clear that under the circumstances there was substantial negligence in relation to that activity in Cambodia, activity that the World Vision organisation brought to the attention of the committee at an early stage during our inquiry.
I might also say that, unfortunately, the government says that it agrees that it needs to cooperate with countries like Cambodia. It said:

. . . the Government has now removed the need to negotiate treaties in all but the most exceptional circumstances. While the Government is not prepared to pursue treaties with Cambodia and other South East Asian countries, it considers that the changes it has made to the scheme of the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987 will remove significant impediments to, and thus facilitate greater cooperation with, countries in our region in the investigation and prosecution of child sex offences.

It did say in its response that it felt that the liaison efforts of the AFP would assist. Unfortunately, in the case of Cambodia, when the allegations were made in the case of a member of Australia's diplomatic mission, the AFP was forced to do an inquiry here in Australia, offshore. The AFP did not even send personnel to Cambodia, and it did not give rise to a prosecution for some time down the track.

I know that the Australian Federal Police Association was particularly disappointed with the response made by the government at the time and by the fact that there was not an onshore investigation in the country where the offences were alleged to have taken place.

In conclusion, I want to make the following point. Nothing that can be done by the federal government in relation to paedophile activity will succeed unless we give the family unit the opportunity, the support, to be able to combat the problem in the first place. I might say also that it is highly disappointing that some of the government's own departments, particularly the Department of Social Security, may well be contributing inadvertently to the problem in the first place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the member for Moore (Mr Filing) for that speech. It was an excellent speech and I agree very strongly with most of his sentiments. It is a pity that events in the Western Australian Liberal Party prior to the last election led to his being a loss to our party because I know on these sorts of issues that he has very strong views, and views with which I agree very strongly.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting that this debate is occurring here today. I would have thought that there would be a list of speakers 25 or 30 long taking the opportunity to speak about this matter here in the Main Committee, given the current climate. I suppose it emphasises the importance of this committee to members. There are other matters on the agenda here today that are equally important in a lot of respects. The Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs report on youth suicide is also on the agenda. There are a limited number of speakers.

In many respects this debate should be going on in the House of Representatives chamber itself because of the fact that it is such an important issue. I am not necessarily being critical of my colleagues, but somehow the processes and the opportunity is not getting through to people, and on this particular issue of paedophilia I would have thought there would have been a lot more speakers.

The member for Moore has a great deal of credibility in respect of what he has had to say this morning. For a start, he was on the committee during its inquiry and he is the only member of the committee who is still on the Joint Statutory Committee on the National Crime Authority, the committee which I currently chair. He was on that committee at the time that it brought down this excellent report, but more than that, as I understand it, he actually drove the committee on this report. It was his knowledge of this subject, as a former policeman, that drove this report.

It is really quite amazing that here we have a report that was brought down in this parliament on November 1995 on a subject that this day is on the lips of every Australian. In 1995 I think most Australians would not have been able to spell `paedophile', let alone know what it was all about. Yet today we have this debate not only following the Wood royal commission but within a couple of weeks of the report of the Children's Commission of Queensland to the Queensland government, entitled Paedophilia in Queensland.

I do not want to overdo it, but let me tell the parliament that the member for Moore has made a very significant and relevant speech here today and he deserves a great deal of credit for the committee's work on this subject. We are dealing now with the government's response to the report. I note that the government has accepted every recommendation made by the committee in its report, but this is only the beginning of a role for the Commonwealth on this subject, because of its importance—which, as I said, has been underlined by events in the last few days.

I do not think anyone would suggest that paedophilia is new, that it is something that has just started to happen. The evidence is that it has been going on for a very long time, but it has been one of those subjects that people have not wanted to talk about. It is not a very nice subject to talk about and I suppose those of us who have had some responsibilities and opportunities to talk about it have probably abrogated those responsibilities by not being prepared to do that.

We now understand, as a result of events in recent days, the extent of this problem and, probably worse even than the extent of it, the actual nature of it, which Justice Wood spelt out not only in his report but in subsequent interviews. I think he was not able to say graphically enough some of the horrific and horrible evidence with which he had been presented on this particular activity. But the Queensland Children's Commission report makes the point, in relation to Queensland, that:
The existence of a hard‐core group of some 300 active paedophiles in the State is cause for a considerable concern.
That has to be an understatement. The report goes on:

When it is recalled that a single paedophile may sexually abuse on average 150 victims, an estimated 45,000 Queensland children consequently are destined to carry the scars of sexual abuse by this 300. To these figures of course must be added many thousands of Queensland men and women who, during their adulthood, are now also bearing the emotional and physical scars of sexual abuse as children.
Studies relied upon by the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence (ABCI) provide a basis for assessing the statistical magnitude of paedophile activity in the State.
These studies suggest that one in four girls and one in eleven boys are sexually abused by the time they reach the age of 18 years.

Out of Queensland's population of persons aged 0‐17 years, some 150,000 will consequently carry the emotional and physical scars of sexual abuse throughout their adult lives. This number will augment the number of existing adults who in their childhoods were also subjected to sexual abuse. That number of persons now over 18 years of age in Queensland is of the order of 420,000.

When it is recalled that 70% of persons in psychiatric units of some of our hospitals are known to have been sexually abused as children, we can begin to see the true dimensions of the societal scourge which paedophilia constitutes.

That report came out on 5 August, just a couple of weeks before Justice Wood brought down his report into the New South Wales situation, which is equally as bad, maybe even worse. So we have a problem that is not only in Queensland, is not only in New South Wales, but, by any estimate, is an Australia‐wide one of enormous proportions.

I want to say that the member for Moore is absolutely right when he puts this in the context of family and family breakdown. I do not know whether there has been any research done about this. Paedophilia has probably been going on for a long time. Certainly, family breakdown in society has contributed to the extent of paedophilia. It is interesting to talk about abuse within the family. There is a headline in my local paper today `Fathers top list for child abuse'. `The most common child molesters are fathers and stepfathers', it says. I would contend—but I do not have the statistics to back it here—that most of that abuse is being inflicted by stepfathers or by a parent in a de facto relationship. That is my contention.

Let me base that on this fact: as far as I can see the abuse of a child by a natural father is at the absolute horrific end of the scale. We are not downplaying other parts of this scale of abuse, which are equally concerning. My guess would be that abuse of a daughter by a natural father would not be a frequent occurrence. Therefore, when we start to see headlines like `Fathers top list for child abuse', I believe the real emphasis is probably going to be on stepfathers and parents in de facto relationships.

One of the problems that the member for Moore touched on is that this sort of debate provides fertile ground for the anti‐family element in our society to get in and say that children are all abused in family relationships and, therefore, families are bad and the sooner the children are taken over by someone outside the family, where they will not get abused, the better. That is what really worries me about where this debate may ultimately go.

What I am sure of—and I have given a lot of thought to this over the years—is that we have in our society a very great problem with the breakdown of family. It leads to all sorts of other problems. Children are hurt by divorce in many ways. Whilst for a while there was trendy evidence coming out to tell us that children are better off if their parents get divorced, the latest evidence and the most persuasive evidence is that that is not the case, and that children suffer from divorced parents for a very long time in their lives. Now we are seeing very strong evidence that when divorces occur and we have these blended families, and blended families on blended families, the capacity for paedophilia—abuse of young children—is magnified because of that many times.

It gets back in my view, as the member for Moore made very clear, to a concern about the state of families in our nation. Whilst he was mildly critical of the performance of the government of which I am a member, I would defend the government. I think this government was elected with a very strong mandate to support families. I believe that we delivered on that commitment and we are further in the process of delivering on that commitment. I am coming very much from a concern as a pro‐family person in this parliament. Aspects of our policies have not moved quickly enough, but this issue may well galvanise us into further action.

The question which has been raised, and it was raised in the Queensland commissioner's report, is what the national response ought to be. The focus therefore comes back almost the full circle on the National Crime Authority and what role, if any, it ought to have in this. In fact, the Queensland commissioner says:

Within the past decade a number of agencies established to focus on crime and its link to corruption of public officials in particular has addressed their role in combating paedophilia. In Queensland, this has involved the CJC and, at a national level, the NCA.
In examining their jurisdictions for paedophilia, both agencies seem to have taken as a starting point, their mandate in relation to organised crime.
They then proceeded to address the question as to whether the available evidence regarding paedophilia suggests an organised activity.

As a result of certain specific characteristics of organised activity these agencies have concluded that paedophile activity does not qualify as an organised activity in the terms of reference specified by them. From the standpoint of the relevant agency such an approach may be justified but, from the wider perspective of community interest and welfare, it does not seem very helpful and it constitutes something of an academic exercise. I tend to agree with the Children's Commissioner there.

The issue of whether there is a role for the NCA in this has exercised my mind. The NCA has completed a strategic assessment of paedophile activity in Australia and the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) currently has that on his desk. My committee has asked to be briefed on the outcome of that assessment. We have asked for the assessment but there will be some very sensitive areas and we may not get the actual assessment. But, of course, we are looking forward to having a briefing on it. I think we can then look closely at whether there are some definitional problems in terms of whether it is organised criminal activity for the purposes of whether the NCA ought to be involved, and we may well proceed to address those particular issues.

The NCA has proved its effectiveness because it can cross jurisdictional boundaries, and so on, in combating a lot of aspects of organised crime. I believe it would be counterproductive to get bogged down in the question of whether paedophile activity is organised crime. The NCA committee, under my chairmanship, will continue to address the issue. The report that the committee did in 1995, driven largely, as I said earlier, by the member for Moore, does I think totally vindicate the concerns he had and his committee had then. Here it is, as I say, two years down the track and suddenly we have on our hands a recognition that we have here a very serious national problem.

As a result of all of those considerations, the NCA committee will continue to focus on the issue. We look forward to seeing the outcome of the strategic assessment. I understand that it largely confirms the findings of this report and indeed confirms Justice Wood's findings which indicated that paedophilia, whilst it was a great concern, was not a nationally organised activity: it was occurring on a local level, within the context of family relations, and it existed in fairly close networks. But, in my view, that should not be, as the Children's Commissioner in Queensland says, the ultimate determiner of whether we address it on a national issue.

The government responded a little further in the parliament yesterday in response to a question about the Wood commission. I would like, if I had time, to deal a little further with the suggestion that there be a national council for the prevention of child abuse. Time will beat me on that but I am pleased that this has been listed for discussion here in the Main Committee today. (Time expired)
Debate (on motion by Mr Griffin) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 27 August, on motion by Mr Reid:
That the House take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin, Stephen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great pleasure to speak in the Main Committee this afternoon on this particular report of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology. I think most members of this House would know that I have always been a great supporter of the role that parliamentary committees can play in advancing ideas to government. In this particular case, I think this is not only a timely report but also one which this government needs to respond to quickly.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, I put on public record that the Australian Labor Party will give swift passage through both the House of Representatives and the Senate to any of the recommendations requiring legislation arising out of the committee's report. I have said that publicly. I have put that on the record in a number of different forums around this country in the last several months as we have talked to people in small business but I think it is the first opportunity that I have had to record it here in the parliament. I think it is important that that be said.

I do not think anybody who has participated in discussions with small businesses, particularly small businesses and franchisees in shopping centres, could be left untouched by some of the stories that these people tell about the complete and disproportionate amount of market power working against the interests of small business.

I have travelled around in my capacity as the shadow minister for small business in the last two months—in the break—and spoken to people in shopping centres in Rockhampton, Wollongong, Melbourne, Newcastle and the Gold Coast. The stories I was told were mirror images of the stories which colleagues who sat on this committee heard in evidence which they received. They were the stories of small business people, micro businesses, and mums and dads operations: in Australia some 50 per cent of businesses are operations run by one or two people, often family members, that do not employ anybody else.

BREAK.PARA: They told stories about the way in which market power was being used by shopping centre management and by owners of shopping centres to disadvantage them, and stories about being forced to relocate within shopping centres to areas where less passing traffic was going to mean a slashing of profitability for that small business and, in many cases, was going to cause it to go to the wall. They told stories about ways in which new tenancy agreements were struck and the way in which the small business person was disadvantaged in those negotiations with a virtual `take it or leave it, and if you do not like it then you are out the door' type of arrangement. When you talk to franchisees of the common franchises that we see in shopping centres about some of the master franchisors they tell stories about the way some of those franchisors—not all of them, but some of them—deal with people. They tell stories about the up‐front fees and the increases in outgoings which small businesses in shopping centres have to put up with.

In one shopping centre I went to in Melbourne, the total cost of outgoings—the moneys that shopping centre tenants pay for things like joint advertising, cleaning, security and so on—was $600,000 in one year. The next year that was put up to $1.2 million. There was no consultation with the tenants. The centre management simply said, `Here's your new bill and you are going to have to learn to live with it. Of course, you will be levied an increased fee for the privilege of having your premises cleaned, guarded and advertised in joint publications.' These are the sorts of issues which are out there in the ether. These are the sorts of problems facing small business.

Much has been said about small business in this country over the last 12 to 18 months and perhaps longer. There are two things I want to say. Firstly, we on our side of the parliament would be the first to concede that when in government we probably did not move as quickly as we should have to protect small businesses from unconscionable conduct, predatory pricing and some of the other issues which have been outlined in this particular committee report. I accept that, and we are moving to try to redress that—albeit, unfortunately, from opposition.

Secondly, I think it is fair to say that in the election in March last year there was a clear expectation from small businesses that if they voted to put the coalition into government they would have friends in court and the coalition would move to support small business. Regrettably, they are telling me that that is not happening. They are telling me that some of the things the Treasurer (Mr Costello) or the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith) are talking about at the moment, like capital gains tax, rollover provisions for retirement, unfair dismissal provisions and so on, whilst they are important to some small businesses, are not the key issues. What small businesses want is a return to profitability. What they want is business confidence. What they want is more people coming through the front door.

But they also want protection. They want protection from unconscionable trade practice. They want protection from some of the activities that certain shopping centre managers embrace as part of their running of shopping centres. In fact, what small businesses are saying is that they want to find a balance. They want to redress the imbalance that presently exists between the small shops and the people that own the shopping centres and manage the shopping centres. They want to make sure that that balance is redressed, with equality in terms of negotiating power at least.

This report makes specific recommendations about that. As I have said, this report goes to issues like franchising and retail tenancy legislation. And, importantly, it says that in both of those instances, we should have legislation through changes to the Trade Practices Act underpinning codes of conduct. We could not agree more. Giving small businesses the opportunity to take on landlords who are unscrupulous, in a fair, reasonable and equal arrangement, is critical to the improvement of small business and its operation.

I think that it needs to be said, also, that access to justice and the cost of access to justice are disproportionate—and examples are given in this particular report. It is very easy for the Woolworths and the other major shopping centre operators in this country to throw a ton of money and a truckload of lawyers at a small business person and bankrupt that person, causing marriage breakdowns and all sorts of difficulties for those people, and not think anything of it.

On the other hand, if there were access to justice through tenancy tribunals, an equalisation of that power relationship which presently is so unequal would occur. Quite obviously then small business would feel much better off and would, in fact, be much better off. They are the recommendations contained in this report.

Much has been said over the past several months about small business. In fact, it cost the former minister for small business, the member for Forrest (Mr Prosser), his position in this government, and we have a new minister now. This minister has said that he is going around talking to people. We all know that the government's response to this report was due last Tuesday. We have said to the minister that if he wants another couple of weeks because he is only new to the job, that is fine. He said that he wanted to talk to people to get an overview of what was going on.

But while he is doing all that, of course, his bureaucracy is out there drafting the response that the government will bring down to this report. I know that there are members of the government parties—those members, particularly, who were part of the committee inquiry—that will be doing their utmost to ensure that their government upholds every recommendation to the last word to ensure that small businesses do get a fair go. As I said, on 2 March last year there was an overwhelming depth of support for this government by small business. They expected to get something. They expected to see opportunities for small business to be improved and, as a consequence of this report now being released—it being known to so many in the small business community—they can only hope that the government will be true to its word.

Not unexpectedly, the other side of the equation—best described, I guess, as the landlords—is fighting back. The landlords have asked Access Economics to produce a contrary view to the parliamentary committee report. This contrary review was put out a couple of weeks ago and it was called Tipping the balance. We all know in which direction that balance was proposed to be tipped when this analysis was done by Access Economics and came out on behalf of the Property Council of Australia. It was tipping it back towards the landlords.

Quite frankly, the criticism that this document levels at a parliamentary committee—almost claiming that a parliamentary committee of the House of Representatives was unprofessional in its approach to an issue—is laughable. I know that someone like you, Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, who is as committed as I am to the way in which this parliament is seen as being so important to the nation's future and, to the fact that our committee system can make, and has made in the past, a tremendous contribution to changing government laws, would be just as offended as I am by some of the comments that are contained in here.

This creates an enormous problem for my good friend the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business. On one hand, he has a parliamentary committee and his own colleagues saying unanimously that small business has got to be looked after. They are saying, `Look after the small business community that voted for us. They deserve an equal chance.'On the other hand, you have got a report from the Property Council of Australia which says, `Don't worry about them; most of them are whingers anyway. Free competition is what it is all about. After all, Minister, the Property Council of Australia translates as landlords, and that translates as plenty of good donations around election time.' That is the balance that this minister is going to have to address.

Much has been suggested about issues arising in this committee report. I am pleased to say that a number of media commentators have picked up on it and have reproduced some of the horrendous stories that were contained within it. But at the end of the day, it is simple for this government. They have a unanimous government report. They have the support of the opposition—and the Democrats, I might say—for enacting the legislative changes recommended in here and the other issues which are required and that will help small business. There is a win‐win situation.

This is one of the truly great moments in Australian politics, where all sides of the political fence are quite prepared to say to the small business community, `We will help you. Here is the document that recommends how that will be done and here is the legislation going to pass through both houses of parliament with the support of every major political party.' I think that it is probably a bit of a rarity in this place to get everybody agreeing with each other.

On the committee, I know my good friend the member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins), who was a very active member in this and played a very real role, and also my colleague the former minister for small business and the member for Rankin (Mr Beddall), had a lot of time and effort which they were prepared to expend with government members in arriving at that joint position on fair trading.

If one quote illustrates the sorts of problems that small businesses have encountered as a result of this inequality in market power, it is the one that appears on page 4 of this report. I would like to have it read into Hansard. It is from an unspecified retailer because quite clearly she did not want to be identified. It reads:

I once had a thriving business in an industry few could match my enthusiasm for . . . [What the retail leases tribunal could not consider is the devastating effect the past five traumatic years have had on me and my family which not even our once rock solid 27 year marriage could survive. We were once confident, positive thinking go‐getters but now we're broke and dispirited relics of our former selves with several stress related health problems, not the least being acute depression, insomnia, nervous tension and obesity. I went through premature menopause and my once cheerful, workaholic, loving partner is now an angry, aggressive alcoholic. Our children suffer too, helplessly watching both their parents fall to pieces before their eyes and their quality of life diminish. At 50 years of age, we've been left with a massive business debt, which we have insufficient earning power to repay, and . . . we now face the real prospect of being homeless as well.

The chains have been allowed to gobble us up and the landlord is allowed to trample us down. Our pleas to politicians fall on deaf ears and the legal system treats us with contempt. The end result is the tragedies exposed almost daily in the national news. Why must it be so? We too are entitled to our place in the sun. [The Fair Trading inquiry] has within its power to recommend that justice is done and if I believed in God anymore, I'd pray that you will ensure it is.

That is from the heart of a retailer who has suffered grievously because of past policies of all governments. Here, with this report, is an opportunity to redress those sorts of problems. The Labor Party, for its part, will help in that process.

I have travelled extensively. I have spoken at retail rallies involving 500 people in Newcastle, 100 on the Gold Coast and 1,000 in Melbourne. They have told me what they want. Yet the minister for workplace relations came into this parliament yesterday and said what people want is capital gains tax rollover relief so they can pocket $500,000 on retirement. The only small businesses that could do that would be people that owned a McDonald's franchise or something similar, not the bulk of small businesses in this country. Respond to this committee inquiry report and justice will be done. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the next speaker, I inform the committee that the children in the public galleries are from the Nambucca Heads Christian Community School, the jewel of the electorate of Cowper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johnston, Ricky, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to speak today on Finding a balance: towards fair trading in Australia , a report which has been brought down by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology. I also welcome the contribution made by the member for Cunningham (Mr Martin), who has just left the room. Whilst I recognise and acknowledge his helpful gesture in putting into place the recommendations that have now been handed down in this report, I am a bit at a loss as to why he and his government had not done just as much in their previous years of being in government. It is rather a bit too late. I must say that, whilst I welcome his gesture of helping, it does seem to be a little bit hypocritical to change his mind so quickly in such a short time.

SPEECH.PARA: Like the member who spoke before me, during my past 13 years of campaigning I too travelled very widely throughout my electorate. During that time I became extremely aware of the fact that small business was very, very adversely affected in a number of areas, particularly in matters concerning franchising, retail tenancy and justice.

There is no doubt that some small businesses were getting the rough end of the stick. In my discussions with those business owners I could sense the frustrations that they were experiencing as a result of what I would often consider to be very unscrupulous business practices. They were forced to work under conditions which were, to say the least, very exploitative in several instances.

There is no doubt that as a committee we heard many stories of anger, disillusionment and complete despondency from small business people due to the treatment they received from big business operators. I believe that small business should be given the opportunity not only to survive but also to prosper, and to be free from the types of predatory practices and standover tactics that they have experienced from these people in the past. I am very proud to have been involved in such a concerted attempt to provide a fair and equitable report. One of the members sitting opposite me was on the committee as well and I am sure he would agree with me that we spent many, many hours listening to some very horrendous stories.

I would also like to point out that I am one of only three women on this committee. Whilst it is personally rewarding for me to acknowledge that an increasing number of women are entering into the small business area, it is also good to know that in the main they are the people who are making a success of their businesses. And perhaps, without wanting to get involved in the gender bias argument, there is something here that our male colleagues could learn from women in business.

BREAK.PARA: The issues that this report seeks to address are based on a real commitment to secure a better deal for small business, which after all is very important in the revival of our economy. When handing down this report, I—along with other committee members—was very much aware of the need to keep to the terms of reference set out by the then minister for small business, the member for Forrest (Mr Prosser). The brief included investigating and reporting on unfair business conduct and dealings, as well as on the social and economic implications of major business conduct issues and their subsequent outcomes.

I would suggest that this report is very timely. For far too long governments have failed to listen to the concerns of small business. Indeed, action to ensure that acceptable and fair business conduct is practised in Australia is now critically important for the successful future of this country. The committee received an overwhelming number of written and personal submissions. It would be less than honest to say that in most of those cases, small business operators did not ask for special protection or special treatment; they simply asked for the opportunity to get a fair deal.

The evidence provided to the fair trading inquiry suggested that small businesses are often very frustrated by what they believe to be unfair commercial conduct when entering into business dealings with larger and more powerful companies. Such behaviour was alluded to as being present in all states of Australia, and, in particular, it centred around tenancy agreements, as we have already heard. Claims were made that major retailers were in a position to insist that developers exclude certain other retailers, and claims were made that franchise agreements were one‐sided, more often than not in favour of the franchisor.

In my own electorate of Canning, many constituents have complained to me about such practices. One retailer situated in a shopping centre was advised several years ago that the centre would be increased in size and revamped. It was suggested that he should be relocated. Since that time absolutely nothing has happened in that centre except that since then this small business operator has been on a monthly tenancy lease. I defy anybody in this room, let alone outside this House, to run a business on such a basis.

In another case, a franchise operator was required to buy his stock through the franchisor. When the franchisee complained that part of the stock was inferior and damaged, he was told that he had no option to refuse it and it was suggested that he should sell his stock at a discount price—a ridiculous practice, I would suggest, for anybody to enter into. Another proprietor of a small business at a local shopping centre, neighbouring my electorate, advised the committee of action taken at the shopping centre against the property manager. She alleged gross overcharging in relation to variable outgoings and promotion levies.

I have mentioned these examples as just a few of those that were brought to the attention of the committee as we travelled around the country hearing submissions, that were subsequently printed in the report that was handed down. The issue of retail tenancy is a matter of much contention, with a need for uniformity and security for tenants. I would suggest that this is a high priority. Predatory practices of big business are just not acceptable.

The committee has recommended the need for contractual certainty to be paramount and for unfair and inequitable agreements to be done away with. It also recommended that a uniform tenancy code be developed to enable utilisation around the country and that this be underpinned in the Trade Practices Act. Establishing merchants' associations in shopping centres and regular statements of expenditure on outgoings and promotions was another recommendation which we believed to be highly desirable.

With regard to franchising, many people see buying a small business as an attractive option for securing a job and as an investment for their future. Indeed, some people decide to buy a business once they receive a redundancy payment. The committee's recommendation that proper business education and research are required when one embarks on franchising—or, for that matter, buying a business—is in my opinion very desirable and should be given a lot of thought.

An argument was put before the committee that part IVA of section 51 of the Trade Practices Act 1974 should be amended to strengthen the stance on unfair conduct. The report outlines an amendment to the act that will incorporate a new provision dealing with unfair conduct in commercial transactions. Again, that is a recommendation that is very desirable.

I believe that all businesses deserve a fair go. Small business should not be excluded from this. I concur with the previous speaker, the member for Cunningham, when he said that there are many small businesses that have been subjected to some dreadful exploitation and standover tactics by larger and more powerful businesses. We do need a balance in business practices. We do need fair play for all dealers. We do not want to have business conduct in this country which is skewed to one side or the other of the market.

We all have to work harmoniously together and we should never really forget that it is the many thousands of small business operators that actually contribute to the wellbeing of this country. They are the people that provide the employment to our future generation. Unless we are able to find a balance in that situation, I am afraid that we will have some very nasty consequences to face. I therefore commend this report to the members here and to the government, and I do hope that we will find a fair balance in future trading for businesses.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins, Harry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to be able to speak to this report, Finding a balance: towards fair trading in Australia , by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology. Developing the report and the inquiry was a very educative process for me and I am thankful to a number of members of the committee who played a great role in the inquiry and assisted me to understand the problems that confront small business. I also thank those that came before us for their assistance in that education.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the dismaying aspects of the whole inquiry process of this report was that so many of the people who came before us came very fearful of retribution. I have never been involved in an inquiry where so many people have asked for their submissions to be kept confidential and for their evidence to be given in camera. I think this reflects the type of atmosphere in which small business operates out in the real world, the way in which they feel concerned about the imbalance in power between small business and bigger business.

I reflect on a person who operates a very successful small business in a shopping centre in my electorate. He came to me with a story that illustrated the problems that he had as a trader within that shopping centre and the problems that he had in operating a franchise. Incidentally he also has another arrangement, which is by way of licence, and there are problems with each of those arrangements. I said, `You have a story that would be of great benefit to the committee. It would be very helpful if you could put it to the committee as a submission and then come forward and discuss that submission.'

I was very distressed when a couple of weeks later I got the feedback that this gentleman, who could have been of great assistance to the inquiry, had decided not to go forward with his submission. He had decided not to take the offer to have a confidential submission or to come before the committee in camera basically because he was too scared of what it might mean down the track for him in his dealings with not only the shopping centre managers but also those who hold the franchises.

The sort of atmosphere that this inquiry was conducted in was in a way surprising. One of the principal people, a leading figure in one of the small business associations, in the last week of the last session said to me, `What was your expectation? What did you think was the situation out there? Was it as bad as you thought it might be?' I had to admit to her that it was much worse. We held public hearings in all of the mainland capitals and a number of public hearings were held here in Canberra. The thing about the stories that we were told was that they were consistent right around Australia.

Wherever we went, people came forward who had tried to put in place small businesses but had failed not just because they were perhaps lacking in skills but because their aspirations were crushed by those who were more powerful. In saying that, I stress that we have to acknowledge that, in the way in which the market operates, there will be people who will go to the wall no matter how well intentioned they are. This report is not talking about those cases: it is talking about the people who, because of the imbalance of power, were not given a chance from the start.

Let us look at the recommendations that we have made about a uniform national retail tenancy code. We have tried, as a committee, to set down in the report recommendations and suggestions that deal with matters that should be covered in a uniform tenancy code to ensure that we redress the imbalance that is there between the tenants and the shopping centre owners and managers. The code would be about simple things such as the need for full disclosure when a tenant goes into a situation about matters that might relate to that person's tenancy.

At the start of the inquiry, I thought the way things should operate was fairly straightforward and simple. I was shocked that, in practice, it did not occur, with great detriment and consequences to some of those people, who took up tenancies understanding certain details about the operation of the shopping centre, which they found had changed. They found that the basis for the number of people attending the shopping centre, and things like that, was overestimated.
Professor Alan Millington, who operates out of one of the New South Wales universities, gave us evidence and, in his submission, he said:

Above all, there is a need for retail property owners to accept that the success of their investments, and their shopping centres in particular, is ultimately completely dependent upon the success of tenants trading from them. Without successful retail tenants there would not be successful shopping centres. To have successful retail tenants owners must allow and assist them to prosper by working in partnership with them, rather than seeking to punish them for their success by . . . persistent demands for ever higher rents irrespective of the ability of retailers to pay such rents.

I thought that what Professor Millington said should have been self‐evident. It seemed fairly logical that the relationship between the property owners and their tenants should be to the benefit of both. But in practice there were just too many stories from tenants about the behaviour that they had had to endure and we would wonder why it occurred. In so many cases in evidence brought before the committee, we wondered why there was this behaviour that forced tenants out, forced tenants to fail and forced tenants to go to the wall?

When we spoke to the property owners and managers, of course, they said that the relationship should be as the professor stated, because it is obvious that, in a relatively symbiotic relationship between the two parties, both can succeed. But there were just too many stories for the committee to ignore the fact that this was not the case. As the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr Martin) has said, it was of concern when the peak body of the property owners and managers came out with their own study and suggested that we were not balanced in the way we treated the evidence and that, in some way, the inquiry lacked professionalism.

I say to those people that, if the complaints that were put to us were not real—and I believe that the overwhelming majority are real and have substance—even if the complaints were based on perception, those property owners and managers have a big problem. As has been illustrated in this discussion and debate, you can still go to a shopping centre and quite easily get together a number of tenants that will come forward with stories of hardship and complaint. For instance, earlier in the month, the shadow minister went to a meeting at a shopping centre in my electorate. I was absent and could not be there. Thirty tenants came forward to describe to the shadow minister, the honourable member for Cunningham, the experiences they were having. Those experiences surrounded things that are difficult for property managers to handle.

This particular shopping centre has undergone a three-phase increase in the amount of space that is available.
